text:
So thank you so much
for all being here.
This has been so incredible.
My work fits right in.

I'm so excited to present some
of my ongoing dissertation work
on allyship in the workplace.

So as I probably don't
have to tell a lot of you,

after the murder
of George Floyd we

saw a huge renewal of attention
on allyship in the workplace.

And particularly,
companies were trying

to cultivate efforts to get
their employees to actually

think about things like
privilege and power

and using words like
privilege and power
as opposed to implicit bias.

And at the time that
this was happening,

I had previously been
studying white guilt

with the incredible
Taylor Phillips,

and we'd been studying white
guilt and white privilege,

and typically finding that
people were very, very
hesitant to admit to having it.

But then 2020 happened, and
we noticed a huge change

where people were really
embracing this concept
of privilege and power.

And so we wanted
to know how this

was going to influence the
programming that they were

going to do and how
they might overcome
these sort of challenges.

And so to understand this,
I conducted interviews

with people who were practicing
allyship in organization.

Compared to Barnini, I
was looking at people
who were doing actions.

So people who were
leading ally ERGs,

people who were doing some
sort of allyship programming,
and they were not nominated.

And in fact, many of them did
not call themselves allies.

So the first thing
that I've learned,

which you've seen
a couple times now,

is that allyship is
incredibly uncomfortable.

So even these people
who were ally leaders

were really struggling with
this holding of this privilege

and also this uncertainty that
they had, saying things like,
I'm a total newbie here.

I'm figuring out
at the same time
I'm trying to lead this group.

It feels intimidating because
I'm on the journey too.
I don't know what I'm doing.
I'm not an expert.

So this is someone
who's actually

leading a group with a
lot of urgency and passion

and still saying, I have
no idea what I'm doing.

And as a lot of
people felt that this

was going to be a big barrier,
saying things like whatever

your position is, if you
start to do this active piece,
it lends to this discomfort.

And this person is
saying, I believe

wholeheartedly corporate America
is not interested in that.

And that was the
belief that we had too,

that this kind of discomfort
would lead to disengagement.

But actually, what we found
has been kind of different.

We've seen a lot of allies
who also kind of embraced
this discomfort.

So I have participants saying
things like when asked,

you know, how do you deal
with the guilt and shame that

comes up with racial justice
allyship, they say things like,
I notice "blood on my hand."

I know "I'm not going to
wipe it off, and that's OK."

And "Maybe the act
of guilt is trying

to" wipe it off as opposed
to knowing it's there.

And I also see people
saying things like,

I like that I have
the guilt and shame.

It's like a knife
"when you cut yourself"

and then you remember
to hold on tighter.

So importantly, these attitudes,
this embracing of discomfort

does seem to be impacting
the kinds of behaviors

that allies take
in that they might

be more willing to take more
risks and give up more things.

So I'm seeing a lot
of allies say things

that "If I'm really
working towards equity,"

that means that I have to
give things up, give things up

that I want-- give
things up that I have,

but also give things
up that I want.

And people also
saying, "for me,"

my responsibility "as
an ally is to be like,

'the house is on freaking
fire,'" because often people
say that.

They don't get--
they won't tell that.

And this person
fully accepts, I need

"to let go of my worry of being
fired" because that's just
what's going to happen.

So I think what's
really important here

is we've been talking a lot
about discomfort in allyship

as a bad thing, as
something to avoid,

but we're also seeing a lot
of people try and embrace that

and how this might impact the
kinds of actions they take.

So I think this is highlighting
the importance of understanding

both what people are feeling
and how they're feeling.

Because the instinct would be
that these kinds of feelings
would shut them down.

But I think I'm seeing
a way that we can really

leverage and embrace this
discomfort to stay committed
to reducing inequality.
And with that, thank you all.
[APPLAUSE]
